Then, ssh onto people.apache.org and confirm the permissions are set correctly:

sect2.title: Promote and update the Website
sect2.para: To promote the site, first log onto people.apache.org. Then:

listitem.para: switch to the website directory:
listitem.programlisting: $ cd /www/incubator.apache.org

listitem.para: Either:
move the previous site to one side:
listitem.programlisting: $ mv isis isis-0.x.w-incubating
listitem.para: where 0.x.w is the previous version was uploaded
or simply delete the site:

sect2.title: Merge changes from branch back into trunk
sect2.para: Because we release from a branch, the changes made in the branch (changes to pom.xml made automatically by the release-plugin, or any manual edits) should be merged back from the release branch back into trunk. There are two ways to do this:

listitem.para: The "official" way is to use SVN's merge command for this (using the "reintegrate" flag):
listitem.programlisting: $ cd .../trunk/framework $ svn merge --reintegrate https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/incubator/isis/branches/0.x.x-incubating/framework . $ svn commit -m "reintegrating release branch 0.x.x-incubating ready for next iteration"
listitem.para: However, you will find that this is very slow (the merge command alone takes something like ~1 hour) and will generate a massive change set which also will take an age to commit.

Alternatively, then, you may well find it easy to perform the edits manually:
one option is to use a directory comparison tool such as Beyond Compare or WinMerge to compare the branch workspace with the trunk workspace.
Set the tool's filters to compare only pom.xml files, because these are the only files that the release process in the branch will have updated and require merging in.
or, you could use UNIX command line tools to perform an update.
The following command will locate every pom.xml and perform in place updates, saving the original file to pom.xml.bak:
find . -name pom.xml -exec sed -i.bak -e 's/0\.1\.0/0\.2\.0/g' {} \;
The above works on Cygwin, too (though you may need to fully qualified the find command as /usr/bin/find).

sect3.para: Open up the src/site/site.xml in the [oai:isis] parent module, and update the <version>:

appendix.title: Key Generation

abstract.para: How to generate keys and subkeys in order to sign a release.

appendix.para: In order that a contributor can make a release it is necessary for them to have generated a key and had that key recognized by other members of the Apache Software Foundation. This appendix describes the steps involved. For further background information on this topic, see the release signing page and the openpgp page on the Apache wiki.

sect1.title: Install and Configure gpg
sect1.para: Download and install GnuPG (gpg), version 1.4.10 or higher.
Then, edit ~/.gnupg/gpg.conf (on Windows, the file to edit is C:\Users\xxx\AppData\Roaming\gnupg\gpg.conf) so that the default is to generate a strong key:

sect1.title: Key Generation
sect1.para: The ASF requires that keys are signed with a key (or subkey) based on RSA 4096 bits. To do this:
sect1.programlisting:
$ gpg --gen-key gpg (GnuPG) 1.4.11; Copyright (C) 2010 Free Software Foundation, Inc. This is free software: you are free to change and redistribute it. There is NO WARRANTY, to the extent permitted by law.
Please select what kind of key you want: (1) RSA and RSA (default) (2) DSA and Elgamal (3) DSA (sign only) (4) RSA (sign only) Your selection?
sect1.para: Specify RSA key:
sect1.programlisting:
Your selection? 1
RSA keys may be between 1024 and 4096 bits long. What keysize do you want? (2048)
sect1.para: Specify key length as 4096 bits:
sect1.programlisting:
What keysize do you want? (2048) 4096 Requested keysize is 4096 bits
Please specify how long the key should be valid. 0 = key does not expire <n> = key expires in n days <n>w = key expires in n weeks <n>m = key expires in n months <n>y = key expires in n years Key is valid for? (0)
sect1.para: Specify key as non-expiring:
sect1.programlisting:
Key is valid for? (0) 0 Key does not expire at all Is this correct? (y/N) y
You need a user ID to identify your key; the software constructs the user ID from the Real Name, Comment and Email Address in this form: "Heinrich Heine (Der Dichter) <heinrichh@duesseldorf.de>"
Real name:
sect1.para: Enter your name, email and comment:

listitem.para: use your apache.org email
the comment should be "CODE SIGNING KEY"

sect1.title: Subkey Generation
sect1.para: It's recommended to use a subkey with an expiry date to sign releases, rather than your main, non-expiring key. If a subkey is present, then gpg will use it for signing in preference to the main key.

note.para: After (binary) release artifacts are created, they are deployed to the ASF's Nexus staging repository. However, Nexus seems unable to retrieve a subkey from the public key server. Until we find a fix/workaround for this, all releases should be signed just with a regular non-expiring main key.

sect1.para: It's good practice to generate a number of revocation certificates so that the key can be revoked if it happens to be compromised. See the gpg page on the Apache wiki for more background on this topic.
First, generate a "no reason specified" key:

sect1.title: Publish Key
sect1.para: It is also necessary to publish your key. There are several places where this should be done. In most cases, you'll need the "armored" " (ie ASCII) representation of your key. This can be generated using:
sect1.programlisting: $ gpg --armor --export nnnnnnnn > nnnnnnnn.asc
sect1.para: where nnnnnnnn is the id of your public key.
You'll also need the fingerprint of your key. This can be generated using:
sect1.programlisting: $ gpg --fingerprint nnnnnnnn
sect1.para: The output from this command includes a line beginning "Key fingerprint", followed by a (space delimited) 40 character hexadecimal fingerprint. The last 8 characters should be the same as the key id (nnnnnnnn).

sect2.para: The armored representation of your public key should be uploaded to your home directory on people.apache.org, and renamed as .pgpkey. Make sure this is readable by all.

sect2.title: Publish to your Apache HTML home directory
sect2.para: The armored representation of your public key should be uploaded to your public_html home directory on people.apache.org, named nnnnnnnn.asc. Make sure this is readable by all.

sect1.title: Attend Key Signing Party (Apache web of trust)
sect1.para: It is strongly advised that the contributor attend a key signing party at an Apache event, in order that other Apache committers/members can in person verify their identity against the key. The process for this is described here and here.

appendix.title: Recreating the Quick Start Archetype

abstract.para: Procedure for recreating the quickstart archetype.

appendix.para: The quickstart archetype is created by "reverse-engineering" the quickstart prototype application that resides in trunk/examples/quickstart. This appendix describes the steps needed in order to do so.

sect1.title: Confirm that the quickstart example application works correctly
sect1.para: The first step is to ensure that the quickstart example application works correctly. These steps can also be used to test a newly created app built by the archetype (to test that the archetype is ok, prior to commit).
The quickstart example application defines a number of modules. These include:

listitem.para: the webapp module
which defines a WAR artifact that bundles the HTML viewer and the (Restful) JSON viewer.
the tests-bdd module
The tests-junit module
which contains a set of JUnit tests that exercise the domain object model using Isis' JUnit integration (ie the JUnit viewer)

sect1.para: Each of these modules defines artifacts that can be run in a variety of waysm and so each must be tested.

sect2.title: Build (and Test) from Maven
sect2.para: The following steps assume working in the directory that holds the parent module

listitem.para: If testing the quickstart prototype app, this is trunk/examples/quickstart.
If testing the application generated from the archetype, then it will be the directory corresponding to the provided artifactId (eg "myapp").

sect3.para: First, check that that the application builds correctly:
If the build succeeds, you should see something like:

The second is the same WAR as a self-contained executable, ie, that can be run from the command-line. This is built using the org.simplericity.jettyconsole:jetty-console-maven-plugin plugin.

sect3.title: Testing webapp viewers using jetty:run
sect3.para: The webapp WAR can also be tested from Maven using the Jetty plugin:
The jetty webserver will continue running until the maven command is cancelled (ctrl-C).

sect3.title: Testing webapp viewers using external servlet container
sect3.para: Optionally, you can also test the webapps by deploying to an external servlet container, for example the webapps directory of Tomcat 7. This is a very quick check that the application can be "deployed" to a production-like environment.

sect2.title: Testing from within Eclipse
sect2.para: Apache Isis provides some additional help for developers who use Eclipse as their IDE. The quickstart app configuration that provides this help should also be tested.

sect3.title: Prerequisites
sect3.para: To fully test with Eclipse, use Eclipse 3.7 with the m2e feature for Maven support. Note that using the m2eclipse with earlier versions of Eclipse may not suffice, because the .launch configuration files that are tested have a reference to org.eclipse.m2e.launchconfig.classpathProvider (whereas earlier versions the key was under org.maven.ide.eclipse).

note.para: As noted above, we do not test the webapps using Eclipse's WTP (web tooling) support, because there are interoperability problems between WTP and m2e. As and when this improves in the future, we'll update this guide.

sect3.title: Importing the Quickstart Project
sect3.para: The quickstart app include Eclipse launch configurations (eg quickrun/ide/eclipse/launch/*.launch. These files have a hard-coded reference to the project file itself, which means that for them to work, the app that will be generated by the eventual quickstart archetype should be imported "in the right way".

To minimize the chance of confusion by users who may not know every obscure feature of Eclipse, the quickstart prototype app is therefore written in such a way that the app should be imported using the defaults in the 'Import Maven projects' dialogue.

note.para: This is different from the way that we import the rest of the Isis framework, where we use Advanced>Name Template=\[groupId]:\[artifactId].

sect3.para: Therefore, import the quickstart prototype app:

listitem.para: File>Import>Maven>Existing Maven Projects
Root Directory=trunk/examples/quickstart
Refresh
Finish

sect3.title: Testing the webapp .launch configurations
sect3.para: The webapp can be started using an Eclipse .launch configuration. This runs the org.apache.isis.WebServer, which basically just bootstraps the application defined in the web.xml file using an embedded Jetty.
Navigate to the webapp/ide/eclipse/launch directory, and right-click Run As > ... on the .launch file. Sanity check the application is running ok.

sect3.title: Unit testing
sect3.para: The tests-junit and the tests-bdd modules both contain JUnit test suites. These can be run from within Eclipse using Run As > JUnit Test.
When run from within Eclipse, the BDD tests will generate their test script in /tmp/concordion (the default location).

sect1.title: Generate the archetype source
sect1.para: When you are happy that the quickstart prototype app is working correctly, it's time to generate the archetype.
Firstly, export the quickstart prototype into a new directory:
sect1.programlisting: $ mkdir /tmp/archetype $ cd .../trunk/examples $ svn export quickstart /tmp/archetype/quickstart
sect1.para: This will export all versioned files into /tmp/archetype/quickstart.
At the same time, copy down the groovy script that will be needed in the next section ():
sect1.programlisting: $ cd ../framework $ cp updateGeneratedArchetypeSources.groovy /tmp/archetype/.
sect1.para: Now switch to this directory and regenerate the archetype:
sect1.programlisting: $ cd /tmp/archetype/quickstart $ mvn eclipse:clean clean archetype:create-from-project
sect1.para: This generates the archetype source in target/generated-sources/archetype.

sect1.title: Perform automated edits to the generated archetype source
sect1.para: Before the archetype source can be used to create the archetype, some of the generated files must be edited. Specifically:

listitem.para: each of the .launch files should be edited so that the PROJECT_ATTR key uses the ${rootArtifactId} rather than hard-coded reference to the quickstart prototype; they also require Maven macro definitions at the top of each file.
the META-INF/maven/archetype-metadata.xml file needs modifying so that:
filtering is applied to these .launch files.
an Apache license is applied to this XML file

sect1.para: Since doing this manually would be rather laborious, this has been scripted using the updateGeneratedArchetypeSources.groovy script (copied down in the previous section, ). So, to make the change, just use:
sect1.programlisting: $ cd .. $ groovy updateGeneratedArchetypeSources.groovy $ cd quickstart
sect1.para: If you want to check this has worked, switch into target/generated-sources/archetype/src/main/resources/archetype-resources and search for .launch files.

note.para: This script is NOT rerunnable (because it results in the .launch files not being valid XML)

sect1.title: Manually edit the generated archetype source
sect1.para: The first edit is to the generated pom.xml file (in the target/generated-sources/archetype/ directory); its groupId should be changed from org.apache.isis.examples to org.apache.isis.

note.para: This is because the example quickstart app has a groupId of org.apache.isis.examples rather than the desired org.apache.isis. Having the quickstart app use the desired groupId seems to trip up the archetype plugin's create-from-project goal, unfortunately.
This edit could be automated, and hopefully will be one day.

sect1.para: In addition, the archetype-metadata.xml file (in target/generated-sources/archetype/src/main/resources/META-INF/maven) lists each of the files that constitute the archetype, using a wildcard syntax). Given that the archetype is generated by exporting out of the subversion/Eclipse workspace, all files should be relevant. Even so, it is probably worth reviewing to ensure that no files have been accidentally included:

listitem.para: there should be no .log files lists;
there should be no .settings directories;
there should be no .project or .classpath files

sect1.para: Update the file if necessary.

sect1.title: Verify that the archetype works
sect1.para: Use maven to build and install the archetype into your local repository:
sect1.programlisting: $ cd /tmp/archetype/quickstart/target/generated-sources/archetype $ mvn clean install
sect1.para: Next, generate a new application from the archetype:
sect1.programlisting: $ mkdir /tmp/test $ cd /tmp/test $ mvn archetype:generate \ -D archetypeCatalog=local \ -D archetypeGroupId=org.apache.isis \ -D archetypeArtifactId=quickstart-archetype \ -D groupId=com.mycompany \ -D artifactId=myapp
sect1.para: This should result in a new application in the myapp directory. Switch into this directory:
sect1.programlisting: $ cd myapp
sect1.para: Then, use the steps described above () to test the generated application.

sect1.title: Commit the archetype
sect1.para: When you are happy that the archetype is good, it's time to delete the old archetype and commit the new.

sect2.programlisting: $ cd .../trunk/framework $ svn delete quickstart-archetype $ svn commit -m "deleting old archetype prior to recreating" quickstart-archetype

sect2.title: Commit the archetype
sect2.para: Finally, commit the new archetype:
sect2.programlisting: $ svn -N add quickstart-archetype $ svn add quickstart-archetype/pom.xml $ svn add quickstart-archetype/src $ svn commit -m "recreated archetype from the 'quickstart' prototype app" quickstart-archetype
